elements.content: Finding a high nuclearity hybrid framework with novel structure and properties by an environmentally benign approach is a really challenging task. Herein, a green strategy for synthesis of a new inorganic–organic hybrid framework solid has been described. The framework contains silver sulfate clusters with nine different silver ions with shortest silver–silver connectivity. The present compound is the first example of nonanuclear silver sulfate hybrid framework with a new topology. The hybrid solid compound shows a highly active Lewis acidic nature for the various heterogeneous catalytic reactions such as cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification with quantitative transformation and recyclability.
elements.clean_text: Finding a high nuclearity hybrid framework with novel structure and properties by an environmentally benign approach is a really challenging task. Herein, a green strategy for synthesis of a new inorganic-organic hybrid framework solid has been described. The framework contains silver sulfate clusters with nine different silver ions with shortest silver-silver connectivity. The present compound is the first example of nonanuclear silver sulfate hybrid framework with a new topology. The hybrid solid compound shows a highly active Lewis acidic nature for the various heterogeneous catalytic reactions such as cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification with quantitative transformation and recyclability.

elements.content: A hybrid silver sulfate framework featuring nine silver atoms in the asymmetric unit with shortest Ag−Ag bond is synthesized under mechanochemical strategy. The framework has a new topology and was found to be a very efficient heterogeneous catalyst for cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification reactions.
elements.clean_text: A hybrid silver sulfate framework featuring nine silver atoms in the asymmetric unit with shortest Ag-Ag bond is synthesized under mechanochemical strategy. The framework has a new topology and was found to be a very efficient heterogeneous catalyst for cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification reactions.

elements.content: Functional organic–inorganic hybrid frameworks are intensively studied because of their fundamental scientific interest and potential applications in adsorption, separation, catalysis, sensor, ion-exchange, and photoluminescence. The bonding nature of inorganic ions play a vital role in structural variation whereas the organic moiety produces multifunctional properties. Constant efforts on research in hybrid framework materials have evolved a variety of inorganic building moieties and organic linkers. In the last few decades, silicate, phosphate, phosphite, sulfate, sulfite, selenate, selinite, borate, carbonate and thiosulfate ions have mainly been used for the synthesis of new hybrid framework materials. Sulfate based hybrid frameworks have not been investigated comprehensively, as few 3d-transition metals and lanthanum based sulfate frameworks have been reported. Our past efforts have resulted in a few hybrid cadmium sulfate frameworks with versatile topology and catalytic activity. As the nitrogen containing aromatic organic ligands can enhance the dimensionality and functionality of the hybrid framework structures, polyazaheterocyles and their derivatives are of particular interest in our present study. Any functional hybrid becomes more exciting when it can be synthesized with a greener approach along with their sustainable applications.
elements.clean_text: Functional organic-inorganic hybrid frameworks are intensively studied because of their fundamental scientific interest and potential applications in adsorption, separation, catalysis, sensor, ion-exchange, and photoluminescence. The bonding nature of inorganic ions play a vital role in structural variation whereas the organic moiety produces multifunctional properties. Constant efforts on research in hybrid framework materials have evolved a variety of inorganic building moieties and organic linkers. In the last few decades, silicate, phosphate, phosphite, sulfate, sulfite, selenate, selinite, borate, carbonate and thiosulfate ions have mainly been used for the synthesis of new hybrid framework materials. Sulfate based hybrid frameworks have not been investigated comprehensively, as few 3d-transition metals and lanthanum based sulfate frameworks have been reported. Our past efforts have resulted in a few hybrid cadmium sulfate frameworks with versatile topology and catalytic activity. As the nitrogen containing aromatic organic ligands can enhance the dimensionality and functionality of the hybrid framework structures, polyazaheterocyles and their derivatives are of particular interest in our present study. Any functional hybrid becomes more exciting when it can be synthesized with a greener approach along with their sustainable applications.

elements.content: Mechanochemical reaction, a promising synthetic technique, leads to formation of product by applying the mechanical force with the addition of a negligible amount of solvent. This strategy is superior from a Green Chemistry point of view as it avoids environmental pollution. Hence, this alternative synthetic approach is readily acceptable for the synthesis of products in the laboratory as well as in industry. Solvent-free or solvent-assisted mechanochemical reactions have been widely used for the past few years to synthesize the metal–organic frameworks, coordination polymers, or hybrid frameworks. In this report, we have applied the high energy mechanochemical strategy to obtain the completely pure hybrid catalyst. The solvent drop grinding strategy was adopted to synthesize the new silver sulfate, [Ag8 (SO4)4(C3H6N6)3] (I), framework compound. The present three-dimensional extended solid has been used for various heterogeneous catalytic reactions due to its Lewis acidic nature. Herein, we are communicating the novel synthetic strategy, crystal structure, characterizations, topology, and various heterogeneous catalytic behaviors.
elements.clean_text: Mechanochemical reaction, a promising synthetic technique, leads to formation of product by applying the mechanical force with the addition of a negligible amount of solvent. This strategy is superior from a Green Chemistry point of view as it avoids environmental pollution. Hence, this alternative synthetic approach is readily acceptable for the synthesis of products in the laboratory as well as in industry. Solvent-free or solvent-assisted mechanochemical reactions have been widely used for the past few years to synthesize the metal-organic frameworks, coordination polymers, or hybrid frameworks. In this report, we have applied the high energy mechanochemical strategy to obtain the completely pure hybrid catalyst. The solvent drop grinding strategy was adopted to synthesize the new silver sulfate, [Ag8 (SO4)4(C3H6N6)3] (I), framework compound. The present three-dimensional extended solid has been used for various heterogeneous catalytic reactions due to its Lewis acidic nature. Herein, we are communicating the novel synthetic strategy, crystal structure, characterizations, topology, and various heterogeneous catalytic behaviors.

elements.content: A single crystal of the present compound was prepared by using solvothermal conditions in the presence of water and ethanol at 125 °C in a Teflon-lined autoclave (see SI). Although the single crystal of compound I was synthesized in the solvothermal condition, the complete phase pure product was not obtained under solvothermal conditions. Once the single crystal was obtained using the conditions above, the pure polycrystalline powder compound was synthesized by a mechanochemical synthetic strategy with the solvent drop approach. The exact molar ratio was ground for 2 h to homogenize properly. Afterward, a few drops of EtOH were added at the time of grinding for improvement of homogeneity. The finely ground mixture was kept inside the oven at 125 °C for 3 days. The pure white powdered compound was characterized by PXRD which shows the purity of the compound (see Figure S1). Elemental analyses (using CHN analyzer) were carried out for a polycrystalline powdered compound and single crystals obtained from solvothermal synthesis. The observed results (C: 6.57%; H: 1.15%; N: 15.59%) of powdered sample matched with single crystals (C: 6.60%; H: 1.13%; N: 15.55%) and calculated elemental percentage (C: 6.64%; H: 1.10%; N: 15.50%). Hence, all further characterizations and catalytic studies were performed using the powdered compound I synthesized by a mechanochemical strategy.

Once the single crystal was obtained using the conditions above, the pure polycrystalline powder compound was synthesized by a mechanochemical synthetic strategy with the solvent drop approach. The exact molar ratio was ground for 2 h to homogenize properly. Afterward, a few drops of EtOH were added at the time of grinding for improvement of homogeneity. The finely ground mixture was kept inside the oven at 125 °C for 3 days. The pure white powdered compound was characterized by PXRD which shows the purity of the compound (see Figure S1). Elemental analyses (using CHN analyzer) were carried out for a polycrystalline powdered compound and single crystals obtained from solvothermal synthesis. The observed results (C: 6.57%; H: 1.15%; N: 15.59%) of powdered sample matched with single crystals (C: 6.60%; H: 1.13%; N: 15.55%) and calculated elemental percentage (C: 6.64%; H: 1.10%; N: 15.50%). Hence, all further characterizations and catalytic studies were performed using the powdered compound I synthesized by a mechanochemical strategy.

elements.content: Crystal Data For I: Triclinic, P1̅ (no. 2), a = 9.7628(2), b = 10.1956(4), c = 16.5042(5) Å, α = 87.646(3)°, β = 76.718(2)°, γ = 86.763(3)°, V = 1595.63(9) Å3, Z = 2, ρcal = 3.346 g cm–3, μ­(Mokα) = 5.162 mm–1, 28844 reflections, 5438 unique, 4595 observed I > 2σ­(I); R1 = 0.0933, wR2 = 0.2577 and GOF = 1.042 for 481 parameters; CCDC No: 1496359.

The asymmetric unit of I contains 56 nonhydrogen atoms, of which four S and nine Ag atoms are crystallographically independent (a). Out of nine silver atoms, Ag(6) and Ag(9) occupy special position (2i) with a site multiplicity of 0.5. Ag(1), Ag(3), and Ag(7) have similar coordination environments (Figure S5–S6). They are coordinated with three oxygen atoms of sulfate units and one nitrogen atom of the melamine unit forming the distorted tetrahedral geometry (AgO3N, CN = 4). Ag(2) and Ag(4) have also shown similar geometry by coordinating with three oxygen atoms of sulfate units, one nitrogen atom of the melamine unit, and one silver ion forming the distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (AgO3NAg, CN = 5). Ag(5) and Ag(8) have similar coordination environments. They are coordinated with two oxygen atoms from sulfate units, one nitrogen atom of the melamine unit, and one silver ion forming the distorted tetrahedral geometry (AgO2NAg, CN = 4). Ag(6) is coordinated with two oxygen atoms of sulfate units, one nitrogen atom of the melamine unit, and two silver ions forming the distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (AgO2NAg2, CN = 5). The remaining Ag(9) forms the distorted tetrahedral geometry by coordinating with one oxygen atom of sulfate unit, one nitrogen atom of the melamine unit, and two silver ions (AgONAg2, CN = 4). Interestingly, nine Ag-ions are showing five characteristic coordination environments possessing tetrahedral or trigonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure S5–S6). The Ag–O bond distances are in the range of 2.246(14)–2.604(19) Å (av. Ag–O = 2.424 Å) and Ag–N bond distances are in the range of 2.216(15)–2.305(15) Å (av. Ag–N = 2.251 Å). There are five distinguished Ag–Ag bonds present in the structure. Ag–Ag bonds are in the range of 2.389(7)–3.315 (2) Å (av. Ag–Ag = 2.953 Å) which is comparable with the earlier literature. There are four sulfate units with average S–O bond distances of 1.443 Å. The sulfate unit possesses an average angle of 109.4°, which is indicative of a regular tetrahedral arrangement. The crystallographic parameters and selected bond distances are listed in Tables T1 and T2.

elements.content: (a) Presence of nine different silver ions, four sulfate units, and three melamine units in the asymmetric unit of I. (b) Connectivity of one melamine unit with three different silver ions forming a 12-membered ring. (c) Unit-cell representation of the compound I.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Presence of nine different silver ions, four sulfate units, and three melamine units in the asymmetric unit of I. (b) Connectivity of one melamine unit with three different silver ions forming a 12-membered ring. (c) Unit-cell representation of the compound I.

elements.content: The present silver sulfate compound has a three-dimensional extended structure. The structure can be understood in a simplified way by taking the silver and sulfate coordination first. As the structure has nine different silver ions and four different sulfate ions, the connectivity of both ions make a three-dimensional extended structure (Figure S8). Six silver ions and six sulfate units form a 12-membered ring in which the melamine unit is connected to three alternate silver ions (b). The presence of melamine units eradicates the porosity of the open-framework structure. Such 12-membered rings grow along three directions to make the three-dimensional extended structure (). The coordination numbers of silver ions are four and five which include various Ag–O, Ag–N, and most importantly Ag–Ag bonds. Interestingly, the minimum Ag–Ag distance is 2.39 Å which is observed for the first time though the metallic Ag–Ag bond distance is 2.91 Å. As silver exists in a +1 oxidation state, the present distance is slightly greater than the ionic distance (2.25 Å) of two silver ions.
elements.clean_text: The present silver sulfate compound has a three-dimensional extended structure. The structure can be understood in a simplified way by taking the silver and sulfate coordination first. As the structure has nine different silver ions and four different sulfate ions, the connectivity of both  ions make a three-dimensional extended structure (Figure S8). Six silver ions and six sulfate units form a 12-membered ring in which the melamine unit is connected to three alternate silver ions (b). The presence of melamine units eradicates the porosity of the open-framework structure. Such 12-membered rings grow along three directions to make the three-dimensional extended structure (). The coordination numbers of silver ions are four and five which include various Ag-O, Ag-N, and most importantly Ag-Ag bonds. Interestingly, the minimum Ag-Ag distance is 2.39 Å which is observed for the first time though the metallic Ag-Ag bond distance is 2.91 Å. As silver exists in a +1 oxidation state, the present distance is slightly greater than the ionic distance (2.25 Å) of two silver ions.

elements.content: Three-dimensional polyhedral view of compound I along the bc plane.
elements.clean_text: 2  Three-dimensional polyhedral view of compound I along the bc plane.

elements.content: The present compound possesses unusual structural diversity as the metal shows the variable bonding connectivity from four to five. Compared to the previously reported silver sulfate framework compounds, the present structure shows the novel bonding connectivity with unique cluster formation. A list of the compounds with silver clusters and their observed properties has also been given (see Table T3). Mak and co-workers have reported two porous silver clusters [Ag16(SO4)8]­[Ag4(SO4)2] and [Ag10(SO4)5]. The complex containing [Ag16(SO4)8]­[Ag4(SO4)2] subunits exhibits two kinds of cages assembled with 12-connected [Ag16(SO4)8] units and 8-connected [Ag4(SO4)2] units. Second complex features 14-connected [Ag10(SO4)5] clusters with highest connectivity Ag­(I) cluster SBU reported until the date. A series of silver sulfate coordination polymers have been synthesized in the presence of bipyrazole ligands by Hou et al. Here, the structural diversity and dimensionality arises mainly due to the flexible orientation of bipyrazole ligands. Tong and co-workers have also reported one luminescent octanuclear silver­(I) cluster [Ag8(SO4)2] with two-dimensional layer structure. All the silver sulfate compounds above have weak argentophilic interactions with Ag–Ag distances above 3.00 Å. Such Ag···Ag interactions are more significant for silver-based framework materials. Beside the silver sulfate compounds, Jin et. al have also communicated one octanuclear Ag8-cluster stabilized with adamentanedicarboxylic acid. The compound exhibits 2D-layer of Ag–Ag interactions including ten kinds of Ag–Ag contacts ranging from 2.98 to3.66 Å. Rao et al. communicated one dimeric silver cluster with cyanuric acid possessing silver sheets of average Ag–Ag distances around 2.95 Å. The literature survey above clearly reveals the distinct connectivity as well as shortest Ag­(I)–Ag­(I) bonding interactions in our present silver sulfate hybrid framework compounds. The TOPOS analysis was also performed to understand the simplified structural connectivity. Three different nodes were presented for silver ions, sulfate units, and melamine units as all the units are containing more than two coordination sites. The overall net is formed by 3-, 4-, and 5-connected 16 nodal points. The point symbol of the net is {3.62.73.82.92} {3.62.73} {32.4.62.7}2 {4.63.82}2 {6.102} {6.82} {63.73}2 {63.83}­{63}5. The detailed analysis showed that the observed net is unique as it forms completely new topology (Figure S11).

Compared to the previously reported silver sulfate framework compounds, the present structure shows the novel bonding connectivity with unique cluster formation. A list of the compounds with silver clusters and their observed properties has also been given (see Table T3). Mak and co-workers have reported two porous silver clusters [Ag16(SO4)8][Ag4(SO4)2] and [Ag10(SO4)5]. The complex containing [Ag16(SO4)8][Ag4(SO4)2] subunits exhibits two kinds of cages assembled with 12-connected [Ag16(SO4)8] units and 8-connected [Ag4(SO4)2] units. Second complex features 14-connected [Ag10(SO4)5] clusters with highest connectivity Ag(I) cluster SBU reported until the date. A series of silver sulfate coordination polymers have been synthesized in the presence of bipyrazole ligands by Hou et al. Here, the structural diversity and dimensionality arises mainly due to the flexible orientation of bipyrazole ligands. Tong and co-workers have also reported one luminescent octanuclear silver(I) cluster [Ag8(SO4)2] with two-dimensional layer structure. All the silver sulfate compounds above have weak argentophilic interactions with Ag-Ag distances above 3.00 Å. Such Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions are more significant for silver-based framework materials. Beside the silver sulfate compounds, Jin et. al have also communicated one octanuclear Ag8-cluster stabilized with adamentanedicarboxylic acid. The compound exhibits 2D-layer of Ag-Ag interactions including ten kinds of Ag-Ag contacts ranging from 2.98 to3.66 Å. Rao et al. communicated one dimeric silver cluster with cyanuric acid possessing silver sheets of average Ag-Ag distances around 2.95 Å. The literature survey above clearly reveals the distinct connectivity as well as shortest Ag(I)-Ag(I) bonding interactions in our present silver sulfate hybrid framework compounds. The TOPOS analysis was also performed to understand the simplified structural connectivity. Three different nodes were presented for silver ions, sulfate units, and melamine units as all the units are containing more than two coordination sites. The overall net is formed by 3-, 4-, and 5-connected 16 nodal points. The point symbol of the net is {3.62.73.82.92} {3.62.73} {32.4.62.7}2 {4.63.82}2 {6.102} {6.82} {63.73}2 {63.83}{63}5. The detailed analysis showed that the observed net is unique as it forms completely new topology (Figure S11).

elements.content: Considering the lower coordination sites of Ag­(I)-ions, we are keen to check its catalytic activity. A catalyst is designed in such a way that it provides negligible toxicity, higher recyclability and shows better cost-effective performance in economic aspects. Recently, metal–organic frameworks and various metal-clusters are extensively used for heterogeneous catalysis reactions along with their multifunctional applications. Our earlier efforts on cadmium sulfate catalysts proved that 4d-transition metal-based frameworks can be used as Lewis acid catalyst. It has been established when a metal center with larger ionic radius is coordinately unsaturated; it can serve as Lewis acid catalyst. In the present compound I, the coordination numbers of silver ions vary from four to five which can accommodate additional coordinating ligands for heterogeneous catalytic activity. The Lewis acid character was examined through a few well-known catalytic reactions, i.e., cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification. The above-mentioned reactions generally require acid as the catalyst to increase the nucleophilicity of the carbonyl and imine-carbon. Instead of mineral acids, the acidity can be achieved by silver-ions as it works as Lewis acidic center with heterogeneous catalytic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Considering the lower coordination sites of Ag(I)-ions, we are keen to check its catalytic activity. A catalyst is designed in such a way that it provides negligible toxicity, higher recyclability and shows better cost-effective performance in economic aspects. Recently, metal-organic frameworks and various metal-clusters are extensively used for heterogeneous catalysis reactions along with their multifunctional applications. Our earlier efforts on cadmium sulfate catalysts proved that 4d-transition metal-based frameworks can be used as Lewis acid catalyst. It has been established when a metal center with larger ionic radius is coordinately unsaturated; it can serve as Lewis acid catalyst. In the present compound I, the coordination numbers of silver ions vary from four to five which can accommodate additional coordinating ligands for heterogeneous catalytic activity. The Lewis acid character was examined through a few well-known catalytic reactions, i.e., cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification. The above-mentioned reactions generally require acid as the catalyst to increase the nucleophilicity of the carbonyl and imine-carbon. Instead of mineral acids, the acidity can be achieved by silver-ions as it works as Lewis acidic center with heterogeneous catalytic behavior.

elements.content: Initially, we checked the catalytic activity of compound I for cyanosilylation reaction as it was studied earlier with silver and cadmium based few hybrid framework compounds. The addition of a cyanide group occurs through the carbon–carbon bond formation in carbonyl carbon or imine compounds. The cyanohydrin products are intermediates in several organic compounds, e.g., aminoalcohal, hydroxyaldehydes, and hydroxyacids. Here, a model imine was taken to perform the catalytic reaction with the finely powdered polycrystalline compound (). The product was analyzed and evaluated for the conversion of the reactants (99%) through 1H NMR spectra (See SI). The catalyst to imine mole ratio was 1:100, which is notable, and the present result shows better activity compared to many Cd-based framework catalysts. The ketalization of various ketones also reflects the Lewis acidic nature of the present compound. For ketal formation, we used three different ketones, i.e., acetone, 2-butanone, and 3-pentanone. All product yields were determined by 1H NMR spectra (See SI). Three different aliphatic ketones have been converted quantitatively to the respective ketals (). In each reaction, we used catalyst and ketone ratio 1:800. The high efficiency of this catalytic activity was successfully observed to various ketones regardless of substrate structure.
elements.clean_text: Initially, we checked the catalytic activity of compound I for cyanosilylation reaction as it was studied earlier with silver and cadmium based few hybrid framework compounds. The addition of a cyanide group occurs through the carbon-carbon bond formation in carbonyl carbon or imine compounds. The cyanohydrin products are intermediates in several organic compounds, e.g., aminoalcohal, hydroxyaldehydes, and hydroxyacids. Here, a model imine was taken to perform the catalytic reaction with the finely powdered polycrystalline compound (). The product was analyzed and evaluated for the conversion of the reactants (99%) through 1H NMR spectra (See SI). The catalyst to imine mole ratio was 1:100, which is notable, and the present result shows better activity compared to many Cd-based framework catalysts. The ketalization of various ketones also reflects the Lewis acidic nature of the present compound. For ketal formation, we used three different ketones, i.e., acetone, 2-butanone, and 3-pentanone. All product yields were determined by 1H NMR spectra (See SI). Three different aliphatic ketones have been converted quantitatively to the respective ketals (). In each reaction, we used catalyst and ketone ratio 1:800. The high efficiency of this catalytic activity was successfully observed to various ketones regardless of substrate structure.

<title>Various Heterogeneous Catalytic Reactions
Observed in the Presence
of Compound I</title>

elements.clean_text: 1  Various Heterogeneous Catalytic Reactions Observed in the Presence of Compound I

elements.content: At last, we carried out the esterification between acetic acid and ethanol with silver sulfate catalyst. Catalyst and substrate ratio was 1:800 similar to the ketalization. Esterification reaction gave a yield of 55% after 10 h reaction at 60 °C with continuous stirring. No improvement to the yield was observed even after longer reaction time. The yield for this reaction was considerably less, but the reactivity appears to be promising as observed in the ketal formation reaction. Blank experiments were carried out for each catalysis reaction under similar conditions without any catalyst, only negligible product formation confirming the effective catalytic activity of silver sulfate. The recyclable nature of the compound was checked for each reaction by performing three cycles. Similar yields were obtained in each cycles and the negligible weight loss of the catalyst was obtained after each cycle. To understand the changes in the chemical environment or structure under catalytic conditions, we examined the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalyst after each catalytic reaction. The PXRD pattern of the catalyst remains completely the same and the amount of the recovered catalyst matches well with the added catalyst (Figure S12). Overall, the high efficiency and reusability presented here prove that our new silver sulfate framework is a new example of Lewis acid catalyst for various heterogeneous catalysis reactions.
elements.clean_text: At last, we carried out the esterification between acetic acid and ethanol with silver sulfate catalyst. Catalyst and substrate ratio was 1:800 similar to the ketalization. Esterification reaction gave a yield of 55% after 10 h reaction at 60 °C with continuous stirring. No improvement to the yield was observed even after longer reaction time. The yield for this reaction was considerably less, but the reactivity appears to be promising as observed in the ketal formation reaction. Blank experiments were carried out for each catalysis reaction under similar conditions without any catalyst, only negligible product formation confirming the effective catalytic activity of silver sulfate. The recyclable nature of the compound was checked for each reaction by performing three cycles. Similar yields were obtained in each cycles and the negligible weight loss of the catalyst was obtained after each cycle. To understand the changes in the chemical environment or structure under catalytic conditions, we examined the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalyst after each catalytic reaction. The PXRD pattern of the catalyst remains completely the same and the amount of the recovered catalyst matches well with the added catalyst (Figure S12). Overall, the high efficiency and reusability presented here prove that our new silver sulfate framework is a new example of Lewis acid catalyst for various heterogeneous catalysis reactions.

elements.content: The applicability of hybrid structures composed by the d10 shell metal ions in the field of catalysis remains uninvestigated where the Lewis acidity arises due to the presence of low-coordinate open sites. The Lewis acidic nature of metal cations can be explained on the basis of e/r ratio (where e = charge and r = ionic radius), which is the basic criteria for the measurement of the electron-withdrawing ability of the metal cations. Although the charge of the silver ion is less, more coordinated unsaturated silver ions increase the efficiency in catalytic reactions. On the basis of the present investigations, a plausible mechanism is displayed in . Here, electron-rich nucleophilic oxygen atoms present on the surface of the Ag cluster framework initiate the reaction and transferred electrons to the trimethylsilyl group of TMSCN, with the formation of a weakly coordinated Si–O bond. The pentavalent silicon intermediate has a weakened C–Si bond and increases the nucleophilicity of cyanide group, resulting in attachment to the Lewis acidic Ag sites. The electron-rich nitrogen atom of imines formed a weak bond with neighboring Lewis acidic Ag sites. Then, a further nucleophilic CN group attacked carbon and formed a cyanosilylated species which comes out as a product in next step. In ketalization reactions, our cation-rich silver-based hybrid framework activates the oxygen of the carbonyl group and permits glycol to replace the carbonyl group. The carbon atom of the carbonyl group undergoes nucleophilic attack by the hydroxyl group of ethyl alcohol resulted in the bond formation between the carbon atom of the carbonyl group and the hydroxyl group of ethyl alcohol with the removal of water. Similar activation will be observed with acetic acid also. But the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon will be the higher in carbonyl group compared to acid group. Hence the complete conversation can be observed in ketones as reported earlier.

The Lewis acidic nature of metal cations can be explained on the basis of e/r ratio (where e = charge and r = ionic radius), which is the basic criteria for the measurement of the electron-withdrawing ability of the metal cations. Although the charge of the silver ion is less, more coordinated unsaturated silver ions increase the efficiency in catalytic reactions. On the basis of the present investigations, a plausible mechanism is displayed in . Here, electron-rich nucleophilic oxygen atoms present on the surface of the Ag cluster framework initiate the reaction and transferred electrons to the trimethylsilyl group of TMSCN, with the formation of a weakly coordinated Si-O bond. The pentavalent silicon intermediate has a weakened C-Si bond and increases the nucleophilicity of cyanide group, resulting in attachment to the Lewis acidic Ag sites. The electron-rich nitrogen atom of imines formed a weak bond with neighboring Lewis acidic Ag sites. Then, a further nucleophilic CN group attacked carbon and formed a cyanosilylated species which comes out as a product in next step. In ketalization reactions, our cation-rich silver-based hybrid framework activates the oxygen of the carbonyl group and permits glycol to replace the carbonyl group. The carbon atom of the carbonyl group undergoes nucleophilic attack by the hydroxyl group of ethyl alcohol resulted in the bond formation between the carbon atom of the carbonyl group and the hydroxyl group of ethyl alcohol with the removal of water. Similar activation will be observed with acetic acid also. But the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon will be the higher in carbonyl group compared to acid group. Hence the complete conversation can be observed in ketones as reported earlier.

elements.content: In summary, we have reported solvent drop green synthesis of new silver sulfate hybrid cluster comprising stability up to 400 °C. The crystal structure analysis has shown the shortest Ag–Ag bond length consisting of nine different silver atoms in asymmetric unit. The compound forms a new topology with 16-nodal points. The hybrid silver sulfate framework is applicable as heterogeneous catalyst for the cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification reactions. The present compound is unique with its structural novelty along with potential applicability. The present study can motivate for the further research on synthesis of new heterogeneous solid acid catalyst by economical and environmentally friendly mechanochemistry.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have reported solvent drop green synthesis of new silver sulfate hybrid cluster comprising stability up to 400 °C. The crystal structure analysis has shown the shortest Ag-Ag bond length consisting of nine different silver atoms in asymmetric unit. The compound forms a new topology with 16-nodal points. The hybrid silver sulfate framework is applicable as heterogeneous catalyst for the cyanosilylation, ketalization, and esterification reactions. The present compound is unique with its structural novelty along with potential applicability. The present study can motivate for the further research on synthesis of new heterogeneous solid acid catalyst by economical and environmentally friendly mechanochemistry.

cln_elements.content: Crystal Data For I: Triclinic, P1̅ (no. 2), a = 9.7628(2), b = 10.1956(4), c = 16.5042(5) Å, α = 87.646(3)°, β = 76.718(2)°, γ = 86.763(3)°, V = 1595.63(9) Å3, Z = 2, ρcal = 3.346 g cm–3, μ­(Mokα) = 5.162 mm–1, 28844 reflections, 5438 unique, 4595 observed I > 2σ­(I); R1 = 0.0933, wR2 = 0.2577 and GOF = 1.042 for 481 parameters; CCDC No: 1496359.

(a) Presence of nine different silver ions, four sulfate units, and three melamine units in the asymmetric unit of I. (b) Connectivity of one melamine unit with three different silver ions forming a 12-membered ring. (c) Unit-cell representation of the compound I.

metadata.title:
First Example of a Nonanuclear Silver Sulfate Hybrid
Cluster: Green Approach for Synthesis of Lewis Acid Catalyst
